title: Nature Bounces Back: The Success of Europe's Master Rewilding Plan
excerpt: From the return of the Iberian Lynx to the recovery of the European Bison, a massive 'Nature Restoration' law is turning the continent's abandoned farmlands into a haven for biodiversity.

content.text: For two thousand years, the story of Europe was one of the constant retreat of the wild. But for the first time in recorded history, the trend has reversed. In 2026, over 15% of the continent's land area is now under 'Active Restoration.' This isn't just about planting trees; it's about 'Rewilding'—the radical idea that if you remove the human barriers and reintroduce the 'Keystone Species,' the ecosystem can repair itself better than any human-led project ever could.

The success story of the year is the 'Iberian Corridor.' By removing hundreds of obsolete dams and connecting fragmented patches of forest, scientists have created a continuous 500-mile 'Migration Highway' for the Iberian Lynx. The population of the world's rarest cat has bounced back from just 94 individuals in 2002 to over 2,500 in early 2026. This recovery has had a 'Cascading Effect,' as the lynx controls the rabbit population, which in turn allows the indigenous scrubland and birds to flourish.

In the east, the European Bison is making a similar comeback. Through a cooperative effort between Romania and Poland, over 5,000 bison now roam the Carpathian Mountains freely. These 'Mega-herbivores' act as natural forest engineers, creating clearings that allow sunlight to reach the forest floor, promoting the growth of rare wildflowers and providing habitats for thousands of insect species. The return of the bison has also brought back the wolves and bears, recreating the 'Climactic Apex' of a balanced ecosystem.

We are teaching the land to be wild again. We aren't building a park; we are restarting a process that has been stalled since the Middle Ages. The result is a more resilient, more beautiful continent.
content.author: Isabelle Moretti, Rewilding Europe Lead

content.text: Crucially, the 'Great Rewilding' is also a rural economic success. Previously dying villages in the 'Empty Spain' and rural Romania are being revitalized by a surge in high-value eco-tourism. Wildlife observers and photographers from around the world are paying to see the 'Big Five' of Europe, creating jobs that are more sustainable and higher-paying than the marginal agriculture they replaced. As the 2026 Nature Restoration Law sets its sights on 30% protection by 2030, Europe is proving that a high-tech society and a wild, biodiverse landscape can do more than just coexist—they can thrive together.
